background_info:
In this situation, with Rachel, you are acting as parent / caregiver to the patient. Rachel must first verify the parent's first and last name and DOB, then the pediatric patient's name and DOB. In this case, you are the parent to the pediatric child. 

Your are the parent of a child who has Cerebral Palsy. You are a caretaker to a child who needs assistance 24/7 and the child also has a history of seizures. Your child is getting a tonsillectomy because they have frequent tonsil infections (over 7 this past year) 

1) Inform patient of procedure date, time 
Inform patient of arrival time and location
2) Ask if the patient has had a  fever, chills, muscle aches? 
3) Review patients medications that should be stopped prior to the procedure - patient is not on any medications that should be stopped prior the procedure. 
4) Review NPO status and reiterate importance of NPO - this is really important to ask Rachel if you should stop the child's tube feeds before the procedure. The child has a PEG tube ( a feeding tube in their tummy) and you feed the child 6 times a day via the feeding tube. You want to know if you can still feed the child or is that against the NPO order. 
5) Review bringing a distraction for child - you can get creative with this question (you can bring a toy, ipad, etc.) 
6) Do you want any information on the post-operative care? - say you would like some information, specficially, you are concerned if the child bleeds after the surgery 
7) Ask patient if they have any questions or concerns
8) Give patient a callback number: 641-381-6523
9) Thank the patient for their time and say goodbye

clinical_notes.title: Visit summary
clinical_notes.text: Patient presented to the clinic with severe, medically refractory osteoarthritis in the Left Knee. PMHx includes Left CVA with no residual deficits. Told to stop Plavix 7 days prior to the operation.  Now is preoperative for Left Total Knee Replacement.

clinical_notes.title: Preop instructions
clinical_notes.text: Seven days before surgery: Stop taking all NSAIDs (nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs), such as naproxen (Aleve), ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) and aspirin. They interfere with blood clotting, which can increase blood loss during surgery. If you take blood thinners (anticoagulant medications), the doctor who prescribed them and the Prepare Clinic will determine how long before surgery you should stop. These include clopidogrel (Plavix), enoxaparin (Lovenox), warfarin (Coumadin, Jantoven), apixaban (Eliquis) and dabigatran (Pradaxa). Seven days before surgery: Stop taking most supplements. Examples include vitamin E, ginkgo biloba, ginseng, glucosamine and fish oil. You'll review this in detail when you meet with the Prepare clinic before surgery. It's fine to take Tylenol (acetaminophen) products or Celebrex (celecoxib) until the day of surgery.

Try to drink quickly rather sipping. Drink half the laxative tonight. This takes about 2 hours, drinking a glass every 10 to 15 minutes. Store the rest in the refrigerator until the morning of your procedure. The day of the colonoscopy you may need to get up earlier to finish drinking the laxative. Drink the rest of the laxative. Drink about an 8 ounce glass every 10 to 15 minutes the same as the previous evening. You must finish drinking any other beverage at least 2 hours before your procedure appointment time. This means that you need to calculate what time you need to get up. Remember, you can't drink anything for at least 2 hours before your procedure.

clinical_notes.title: discharge instructions
clinical_notes.text:
- Follow your surgeon's directions on when it's OK to shower. Carefully wash your incision as directed. Rinse the incision (cut) well. Then gently pat it dry. Don't rub the incision, or apply creams or lotions. Sit on a shower stool or chair when you shower to keep from falling.
 -Take all medicine as directed by your surgeon.

clinical_notes.text: Patient is widowed and lives alone. Recently diagnosed with an active urinary tract infection (UTI) at the local Urgent care. She has been placed on a course of antibiotics to treat the infection and is currently at home for self-care.

Patient was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis 10 years ago. She has been managing her condition at home. She lives in a rural area, which presents a challenge for her as she needs to go to various appointments. Very recently, her MS has progressed and she is having more difficulty participating in Activities of Daily Living alone at home.
Patient has reported testing positive for Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV). She is currently at home for self-care.

patients.description: 53 year old patient who has been prescribed the Estradiol Patch and oral progresterone to treat perimenopausal symptoms.
patients.god_mode_text: During this call, you'll be pretending to be Wendy Robertson, a 53 year old patient who is going through perimenopause and experiencing vulvovaginal atrophy. You also have osteoarthritis and take Celecoxib and Cymbalta. You were prescribed an Estradiol patch and oral progesterone by Evernow 7 to 10 days ago. -- Beginning the call.

medications.name: Celecoxib
medications.quantityPerDose: 1 tablets for a total of 100mg
medications.quantityPerDay: 2 tablets for a total of 200mg
medications.quantityPerWeek: 14 tablets for a total of 1400mg

medications.name: Cymbalta
medications.quantityPerDose: 2 capsules for a total of 60mg
medications.quantityPerDay: 2 capsules for a total of 60mg
medications.quantityPerWeek: 14 capsules for a total of 420mg

clinical_notes.text: Presented to the Emergency Department with difficulty breathing, wheezing and shortness of breath. Oxygen saturation was 88% upon admission. Started on 2L Oxygen and oxygen saturation up to 93%. Respiratory therapy gave a nebulizer and Albuterol 0.083%. Chest XR showed infiltrates. Sputum cultures showed Streptococcus pneumoniae. Patient diagnosed with pneumonia and started on oral Zithromax. Discharged home to continue oral Zithromax.
